Context:
The George Brown College offers an Honours Bachelor of Early Childhood Leadership degree completion program. The program includes an industry internship which is unpaid and required. Students have the opportunity to conduct research in an area of their choice before completing their degree, and will study human development from various perspectives such as developmental psychology, population health, neurobiology, sociology, and anthropology. Teaching and learning is studied through an early childhood lens with a focus on curriculum planning and design.

The program includes field placements in each year, the longest being a 14-week full-time internship between semesters 6 and 7. This internship may be local, elsewhere in Canada or in an international setting. Career options for graduates include moving into supervisory, director and curriculum leadership positions in early childhood programs.

George Brown College owns and operates Ontario's largest network of school-owned and operated child care centres, with 12 centres located across Toronto serving over 1,000 children each year. Some field placement partners may require students to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19.

Career & Postgraduate Study Opportunities:
- Career Options: graduates will be prepared to move into supervisory, director and curriculum leadership positions in a full range of early childhood programs.
- Field Education Options: field placements are offered in each year, the longest being a 14-week full-time internship between semesters 6 and 7.
- Owner and operator of Ontario's largest network of school-owned and operated child care centres with 12 centres located across Toronto.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Bachelor of Early Childhood Education – Honours Program (Degree Completion) C305 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Early Childhood Education (ECE) program at Toronto Metropolitan University prepares graduates for positions as Registered Early Childhood Educators (RECEs) in full-day early learning programs. They will be prepared to guide and lead curriculum and pedagogy in various early childhood settings such as child care centres, family drop-in programs, early intervention services, family support programs, and Emerging Best Start Child and Family Centres.

Graduates with a previous ECE degree who wish to pursue further education have successfully gained admission to master's degree programs and/or the faculty of education at notable universities, including Toronto Metropolitan University's Master of Arts in Early Childhood Studies.

The required courses for the Honours Bachelor of Early Childhood Education degree program include:
- ECL 2102: Applied Research Methods
- ECL 3101: Quality Assurance for Early Childhood Programs
- ECL 3102: Leadership in Learning Organizations
- ECL 3103: Leadership in a Technological World
- ECL 3201: Human Development: Current Topics
- ECL 3202: Building Healthy Communities: Advocacy and Leadership
- ECL 3205: Internship Seminar
- ECL 4102: Curriculum Leadership in Early Learning and Care
- ECL 4103: Managing Projects as an Early Childhood Leader

Students are required to complete a third-year internship, which is a 14-week work experience in an early childhood program, a related child and family service, or a relevant government department. Internships may be local, elsewhere in Canada, or in an international setting.

Relevant post-graduate study opportunities offered by Toronto Metropolitan University include the Master of Arts in Early Childhood Studies.

Context:
Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Analyze the interacting social and biological forces that shape early brain development and lifelong learning, behavior, and health.
2. Respect families' central role in child-rearing and early learning and the impact of family structures, community support systems, culture, and socioeconomic status on parenting.
3. Lead the design and implementation of inclusive, effective curcurricula for young children based on critical analysis, observation, current research, and understandings of early human development.
4. Develop inclusive early intervention programs that respond to children with identified special needs.
5. Evaluate early childhood programs, engaging stakeholders in the process and addressing diverse needs of young children and families.
6. Acquire self-knowledge, critical thinking skills, and professional habits of mind essential to early childhood education practice and leadership.
7. Apply research skills, including assessment of the research process, formulation of research questions, and collection and interpretation of data in a variety of research projects.
8. Establish responsive and reciprocal relationships with children, families, colleagues, and other stakeholders.
9. Perform responsibilities in a manner consistent with ethical and professional codes of conduct, legislative and legal requirements, and defined scope of practice limitations.
10. Advocate on behalf of children, families, colleagues, and the broader community, promoting the principles of quality in early childhood programs.
11. Apply the principles of human resources, financial, and facilities management to the operations of an early childhood program.
12. Collaborate with early childhood educators and other professionals in multidisciplinary or cross-sectoral environments and across diverse domains of practice.
13. Communicate in a professional manner in all verbal, non-verbal, and written mediums.

Courses:
1. ECL 4111 - Research in Early Childhood Studies
2. ECL 4211 - Current Issues – Leadership for Quality (independent studies)
3. LHUM 1215 - Social Policy in Canada

Liberal Studies electives to be selected: two from ECL and one from LHUM

Semester 8

Context:
The text provides information about fees for programs starting in Fall 2023 and Fall 2024 at George Brown College. The estimated total tuition, materials, student service, and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2024 are listed, but are subject to change. Tuition fees are also subject to board approval, while material, student service, and ancillary fees are estimated based on prior years. All fees do not include books, which are to be purchased by the student separately. Students will be required to purchase books and other course materials, and there is an additional cost for internships. International students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information. The program is approved for OSAP funding if the applicant meets eligibility criteria. Admission requirements include:

1. Early Childhood Education (ECE) diploma with a minimum program GPA of 2.5, or
2. Early Childhood Education (ECE) diploma and three years related work experience in ECE with resume and reference letters, or
3. Completion of three George Brown College Continuing Education bridge courses by mid-August with a minimum grade of B- (B minus), or
4. A Liberal Studies course completion prior to completing Year 3 of the program, or
5. Attendance at an online information session (appointment only).

English language proficiency requirements include:

* George Brown College ESL Level 9, or
* TOEFL 84 overall and 21 in each skill band (online), or
* IELTS 6.5 overall and 6.0 in each skill band, or
* MELAB 85, or
* CAEL overall 70 (writing 60).

No specific program name is mentioned in the text.

Context:
* MELAB score required is 85.
* CAEL overall score required is 70 with a writing score of 60.
* International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Course exemptions can be found on the Transfer Guide page.
* Field placement requires standard first aid with CPR level C course, police vulnerable sector check, and medical clearance.
* Students unable to provide completed field clearance documents may not be able to complete the program.
* Advanced standing entry to third year of Honours Bachelor of Early Childhood Education program starts in September.
* Three Continuing Education "Bridge" courses must be completed with a minimum grade point average of 2.5: ECE 2058, Competent Learner; ECL 1002, Introduction to Early Childhood Leadership; ECL 1308, Human Development; and ECL 1205, Composition & Rhetoric.
* Applicants accepted into the program will be assigned a faculty advisor and a faculty supervisor who will also supervise the independent study in Year 4.

Context: George Brown College has been granted a consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities to offer an applied degree in Early Childhood Education for a seven-year term starting August 29, 2017. The college will apply for the renewal of the consent 12 months prior to its expiration. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through George Brown College Online Application System. For more information about the program, contact the School of Early Childhood at 416-415-5000 ext. 2310 or ece@georgebrown.ca. Related programs include Early Childhood Education (C100) and Early Childhood Education (Consecutive Diploma/Degree) (C118). International students can contact George Brown College's international recruitment representatives through the International Contact Us page or by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry. The Toys or Tools applied research project provides opportunities for students to gain academic experience and develop critical thinking skills. Application resources are available by signing up on the campus website.
